research_source: My child is missing‚Äù: 911 calls in mysterious disappearances of children

preferred_locations: Public or outdoor settings for sexually motivated offenders (parks, open areas, places where children are briefly alone)
Homes or residential settings for false allegation cases involving caregiver abuse
motive_patterns.risk_escalation: False allegation cases show escalating household instability, interpersonal conflict, and recent family structure changes leading up to the incident.
decision_factors: Child age strongly influences abduction motive categories
Offender gender varies by motive (males overwhelmingly in sexual; females in maternal-desire cases)
Opportunity and lack of witnesses increase likelihood of non-familial offenses

behavioral_indicators: Evasion when responding to dispatcher questions
Attempts to convince the dispatcher by repeating key phrases
Initial delay in speaking after call is answered
Extraneous information presented outside question context

temporal_patterns.duration_patterns: Call lengths ranged widely (39 seconds to ~16 minutes), but duration did not differ between truthful and false allegation callers.
temporal_patterns.escalation_timeline: In false allegation cases, escalation stems from household instability, abuse, or major family changes leading up to the reported disappearance.

risk_factors: Child age under 5 (strongly associated with false allegations and fatal abuse)
Male children more likely to be victims in false allegation cases
Younger caregivers more likely to be FAC (False Allegation Callers)
Recent changes in household structure (new partners, moves, conflict)
History of severe discipline or physical abuse

movement_patterns.typical_distances: Most cases are local, with offenders or caregivers acting within the immediate residential or surrounding area.
common_routes: Residential movement within the home or neighborhood
Public outdoor paths or parks (sexual-motivation cases)
transportation_methods: No transport in false allegation cases (child already deceased)

training_examples.narrative: A caregiver reports their 3-year-old son missing after claiming he wandered off. Caller hesitates and repeatedly says 'I think he just disappeared.' Investigation shows caregiver had inflicted fatal abuse earlier in the day.
temporal_markers: Child last seen 'sometime earlier' with vague time
Reported disappearance time unclear or not provided

training_examples.narrative: A mother reports her daughter missing at a park. Provides clear sensory details and immediate timeline. Displays urgency and anxiety. Investigation confirms stranger abduction attempt.

A caregiver calls 911 claiming their child was kidnapped but begins the call by explaining their personal activities first. Provides information in an inappropriate order and contradicts earlier details.
